Posts.Content:
Better safe than sorry.
I had a lump and was informed by my Dr not to worry because 90% of these turn out to be nothing serious. But two years down the line it turned out to be stage 2 BC and invaded 2 nodes. I so regret not doing anything about
 it when I first discovered the lump.
So pls go and check it out.
Posts.Title: Do you think i have breast cancer?

Posts.Content:
I totally agree with you. They've taken every single oz of fat I had in my stomach and I still can't stand up straight because It feels too tight and if I do I can't breath in properly. Luckily only one of my rectus muscles have been used.
After surgery my stomach was curved inwards for about
 a week then the seromas started to force it out into a bulge which is what I have now. My PS said it's nothing to worry about
 and should be absorbed within 6-8 weeks. It just feels horrible when i am up and about
 the fluid inside just feels uncomfortable.. I'm going through chemo and the healing seems to have slowed down, or in fact made things worst.
Is it true that you will never be able to do sit ups again?
I don't think the tram flap surgery is suitable for people as thin as me.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction problems coupled with new chemo - for LadyGaga

Posts.Content:
Wondering if anyone has similar experience.
I had an immediate Tram Flap reconstruction on 14th December 2010, that's 7 weeks ago, since then had one chemo treatment at week 6. I am very thin only 100lbs 5'2' and was not informed that it was not a good surgery to have if you are too thin. I would not have gone through it if I'd known. The surgeons strongly recommended this type of surgery to me and I wish I'd known what I know know.
Since then I have had seromas in the abdomen which is still lingering around and trouble breathing and it's really bothering me as I am now not able to eat much at all. How long will this breathing problem stay? I've spoken to my PS and he told me it's early days and it's going to be more difficult because you are so thin. The chemo seems to have made the situation worst.
I wonder if anyone has had similar problems and if this feeling will go away soon. The muscle is like a rock in the middle separating my body.
How long do I have to wait for it to go down?
Posts.Title: Settled on type of reconstruction

Posts.Content: Thks for your help and concern LdyJane
Posts.Title: Reconstruction problems coupled with new chemo - for LadyGaga

Posts.Content: Thks Bev, I will ask my PS on my next appointment, I am also starting to have back pains because my abdomen still fells really tight and it's been eight weeks post surgery now. The breathing is probably due to the tightness of the whole area. When I try to take a deep breath the skin along my body is pulled so tight that my lungs are not able to extend to it's full capacity. Yoga may help.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction problems coupled with new chemo - for LadyGaga
